generated_json.title: History of present illness
content: The patient, Venisha, reports ongoing irritable bowel symptoms as her primary concern. She describes her condition as manageable but notes that the pain has become increasingly severe, significantly impacting her quality of life. The pain is primarily localized to the hip, groin, and thigh, occasionally radiating to the knee and shin. She denies any numbness or sensory changes in the lower extremities. The patient states that the pain has been present for many years and has progressively worsened, affecting her ability to perform daily activities such as bathing in a traditional Japanese style, which requires kneeling. She reports using ibuprofen and Tylenol for pain relief, but these have provided only minimal improvement. The patient expresses significant anxiety about the upcoming surgery, citing concerns about anesthesia, low sodium levels (132), and the possibility of complications such as bleeding, infection, blood clots, fractures, dislocation, and temporary numbness in the lateral thigh due to nerve involvement. She is also concerned about postoperative pain management and the potential for constipation from pain medications. Despite these concerns, she acknowledges that the surgery is necessary due to the impact on her daily functioning and overall well-being.
generated_json.instruction:
Provide a detailed summary of the patient's current illness based on their report. Include a thorough description of symptoms, noting their onset, duration, and severity. Discuss any changes or developments in symptoms since onset and identify factors that may exacerbate or relate to these symptoms, such as specific activities, foods, or medications. Document any prior treatments or remedies the patient has attempted, noting their efficacy. Describe how these symptoms impact the patientâ€™s daily activities, overall well-being, and quality of life. Capture information about any individuals mentioned by the patient, specifying their relationship and any pertinent interactions or conversations related to the illness.

Ensure that no information regarding the treatment plan is included.

generated_json.title: Past Medical History
content: The patient has a history of low sodium (132) and mild iron deficiency. She was advised by her primary care physician to retake the sodium test due to concerns about the level. She was informed that she may require a blood transfusion in the future. She has no known history of blood clots or current use of blood thinners. She denies any known allergies. She has been diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome, which has been a chronic condition for many years.

generated_json.title: Social History
content: The patient is a non-smoker. She denies alcohol consumption and illicit drug use. She is currently preparing for surgery and has arranged for postoperative support from a professional agency (New Wave), a neighbor, and a friend. She will be accompanied by her dog during recovery. She is planning to return home the day after surgery and has arranged for home therapy.

sub-section.title: Assessment
content: Chronic hip pain secondary to degenerative joint disease, likely requiring total hip replacement.
Irritable bowel syndrome (chronic).
Mild hyponatremia (sodium 132 mmol/L).
Mild iron deficiency anemia.
Anxiety related to upcoming surgery and postoperative recovery.
sub-section.default: No assessment
sub-section.instruction: Generate a list of the patient's current medical conditions, Only give me current assessment and not historical information return it in a list

sub-section.title: Plan
content: Proceed with scheduled total hip replacement surgery on Saturday in the early afternoon.
Prescribe Norco (hydrocodone/acetaminophen) for postoperative pain as needed.
Prescribe baby aspirin 81 mg twice daily for 30 days postoperatively for thromboprophylaxis.
Advise patient to use Tylenol as first-line pain management and avoid narcotics unless necessary due to side effect profile.
Recommend use of over-the-counter Benadryl or melatonin for sleep if needed, but avoid prescription sleep aids preoperatively.
Arrange for home physical therapy following discharge.
Patient to be discharged home the day after surgery.
Follow-up with the provider in two weeks postoperatively to assess recovery and mobility status.
Expectation for patient to be off assistive devices (walker, crutches, cane) by six weeks postoperatively.
Educate patient on risks of surgery including bleeding, infection, blood clots, fractures, dislocation, and transient numbness in the lateral thigh.
Reassure patient that anesthesia team has cleared her for surgery given her current sodium level and that saline with added electrolytes can be administered intraoperatively if needed.
sub-section.default: No plan
sub-section.instruction: Detail the healthcare provider's plan of action to manage the patient's condition, specifying treatments, medications (include ongoing medications briefly), procedures, therapies, lifestyle modifications, referrals to specialists, patient education on condition and medications, and recommendations for counselings or support services.
